United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.case_name: United States v. Louisiana (Texas Boundary Case)
United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.title: Oral Argument - November 18, 1968

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: My best memory is that at least the decree in the California case set out the definition of coastline in terms that at least imply a movable coastline when it is related to the natural shore that is where it is, the natural shore is in open contact with the sea.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: I had taken it that that was the unanimous view of the meaning of a boundary, an international boundary under the international convention.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: The Court having adopted for the purpose of inland waters, the international rules, I had supposed the same was true here with the three-mile limit or in this case, the nine-mile limit is defined by reference to the shore rather to the line of inland waters.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, assuming that the position has not been precluded or forbidden by Mr. Justice Harlan's opinion in the California case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Would it be rational third alternative argument to say that the three league limitation from the coastline means not the coastline as of 1845 and not the present and future coastline wherever it may be but the coastline as it was described by Congress that enacted the statute referring to it in the year 1953?

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: Well, I only see two difficulties with it Mr. Justice Stewart.

United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.speaker: Justice White
United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.case_name: United States v. Louisiana (Texas Boundary Case)
United States v. Louisiana (Texas Bounda.title: Oral Argument - November 18, 1968

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: But I would think one might also and this is somewhat hypothetical run across problems of a narrowing of that belt to the point where Texas would almost lose some of its lands or Louisiana might, if you got a very shifting boundary.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: If you fix it as of any given time, and there's a substantial accretion, you presumably have no longer any water belt around you.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: This notion of the shifting belt is more consistent with as I think normal property rules.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But the basic thing is that as Mr. Justice Stewart's, it's the only purpose of the three-league provision.

context.speaker: Louis F. Claiborne
context.text: Well, I don't see Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The is basic premise for the --

Allen v. State Board of Elections.speaker: Justice Stewart
Allen v. State Board of Elections.case_name: Allen v. State Board of Elections
Allen v. State Board of Elections.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1968

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It wouldn't make any difference what the racial makeup was in terms of the statute.

context.speaker: Elliott C.Lichtman
context.text: I think that's correct, but I think the particular facts are illustrative of what Mississippi is trying to do.

context.speaker: Elliott C.Lichtman
context.text: But, technically,Even if the counties were split evenly, Black and White, the new law would still have to be submitted to the Attorney General.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Lichtman, when you answered Mr. Justice Harlan that you thought a statute submitted to the Attorney General would've been approved, now was that answer with relation to the question he put to you namely a statewide statute or are you saying that at this statute?

context.speaker: Elliott C.Lichtman
context.text: I was answering, I thought, his hypothetical question which referred to a statewide statute.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But you -- is that your view?

Allen v. State Board of Elections.speaker: Justice Brennan
Allen v. State Board of Elections.case_name: Allen v. State Board of Elections
Allen v. State Board of Elections.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1968

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In one of these cases we have a Fifteenth Amendment claim, don't we?

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: Yes, not --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But you don't -- you're not suggesting that.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: As I now understand your answer to Mr. Justice White, that the fact of that challenge invokes the three-judge Court provision in it of itself.

context.speaker: Stephen J. Pollak
context.text: Well, Mr. Justice White has analyzed that to, correctly I believe --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In other words, there's no statute.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Klitgaard
context.text: You have to look at the facts, look at how they split in.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But when this -- certainly the Court of Appeal for the First Appellate District of your state, when the case was before for the third time not the second time,--

context.speaker: Thomas J. Klitgaard
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- this is what Justice Fortas read, but for the third time, after it has been remanded in the light of Chapman.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Klitgaard
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: First, it was really granted as I understand it the light of Griffin.

context.speaker: Thomas J. Klitgaard
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Would for just a moment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Get back to this threshold question we seem to have in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Justice Brennan asked your brother counsel about the statement in your reply brief saying it was doubtful that State's Supreme Court could have granted review even had it want it too in citing those -- citing two cases.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Do those cases really standard for it?

context.speaker: Thomas J. Klitgaard
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: James C. Larrimer
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Not at the time that he leaves?

context.speaker: James C. Larrimer
context.text: That's right Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I thought you'd said the opposite to Justice Black.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I thought you said that he came back at the pay that he left with.

context.speaker: James C. Larrimer
context.text: As a matter of fact, he did, but that was --

context.speaker: Dean H. Bilton
context.text: But this is a very important section though because it is the one that allows us to cope with new and inventive crooks.

context.speaker: Dean H. Bilton
context.text: The other subsections are ones that are the traditional extortion elements, the blackmail elements, the threats in the reputations.

context.speaker: Dean H. Bilton
context.text: This section is the one that allows us not to sit back and let a person commit extortion that isn't covered by the other section and if he commits, if he threatens a crime then we move in.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me go back to your responds to Mr. Justice Stewart's question if by whatever process it is determined that the injunction that there was no jurisdiction issue an injunction here in the three-judge court then, there is nothing here on the declaratory judgment because that would not be here, would it?

context.speaker: Dean H. Bilton
context.text: Well, if this Court did rule that the appellants -- appellees had no standing to bring their complaint to the District Court --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But they know you can't get a three-judge court for declaratory judgment standing alone, can you?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: Should this go in because it’s a part of an alleged confession?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: Should the prosecution be entitled to use this as an attempt to prejudice the jury against the defendant?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: We respectfully submit that the issue in this case is quite simple and the issue is to what extent the evidence of prior convictions should be allowed to go in on behalf of the prosecution.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But, as Mr. Justice Stewart asked you, was the federal question which you raised here decided at all in the lower Courts?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: No, sir, it was not.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So, there’s been no state decision on any federal question--

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And the Supreme Court opinion did not treat it on the ground of constitutional error, did it?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: No, sir, it did not.

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: We took the--

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Then, how-- what is the answer to Justice White’s question?

context.speaker: Nathan Greenberg
context.text: The issue as to constitutionality was not raised prior to the time of the preparation of the application for the writ to this Court.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Then do we have any jurisdiction to go through it?

context.speaker: Eugene E. Huppenbauer, Jr.
context.text: The rates separate and apart from the expansion or the improvement of the facilities to landed areas within the community.

context.speaker: Eugene E. Huppenbauer, Jr.
context.text: I realize there are some tie-in but it is not a direct affect.

context.speaker: Eugene E. Huppenbauer, Jr.
context.text: There is some distinction.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I'd like to get back to something that Mr. Justice Stewart asked you.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Reading the record here, I gather that there is Louisiana Power and Light Company, a privately owned utility operating in the city, is that right?

context.speaker: Eugene E. Huppenbauer, Jr.
context.text: It operates -- there is a segment of that utility company very definitely operating in the city.

Federal Marine Terminals, Inc. v. Burnsi.speaker: Justice Warren
Federal Marine Terminals, Inc. v. Burnsi.case_name: Federal Marine Terminals, Inc. v. Burnside Shipping Company
Federal Marine Terminals, Inc. v. Burnsi.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 15, 1969

context.speaker: Paul McCambridge
context.text: He has not spoken once in the area of whether there has been a breach of any implied warranty by the shipowner.

context.speaker: Paul McCambridge
context.text: We claim he is alleging merely tortuous conduct.And --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: May I -- may I interrupt there just a moment.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I understood you a moment ago to say to Mr. Justice Fortas that the petitioner is entitled to subrogation of the $30,000.00.

context.speaker: Paul McCambridge
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now you say that he is entitled to no relief.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: Our point is that the question of equivalency is primarily a legislative judgment and that if we can show that the judgment made by one legislature, in this case, the Congress, it is within the general scope of the laws and practices of the nation as a whole, then, that is sufficient to defend the judgment.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: In fact, it seems to me that it might be the converse if you asked about the particular probation imposed in a particular case.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: You might get into just the problem which concerns you.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, I understood you to answer Justice Black to the effect that these particular conditions were not honorous and that it might be different if they had been.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: No, I think I was trying to make a slightly different point.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I see, alright.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: There are nine -- nine jurisdictions in which the question is left to the Court's discretion and the remainder provided for maximum between one and three years with the great majority in the upper half of that reign.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: While we were able to supply the Court with figures regarding the practice of United States Commissioners in probation cases, which indicates that they regularly imposed probation sentences or probation terms, I should say, in excess of six months, of course is the limit of their authority under -- as far as jail sentences are concerned under the Code.

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: We have been unable to obtain such figures for the nation as a whole, but --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Do I understand you, Mr. Strauss, to say in response to a question by Mr. Justice Black, that if the probation period here had been five years, it might -- you might regard it differently?

context.speaker: Peter L. Strauss
context.text: No, I'm still --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: So i as I mistaken in that?

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: Well, of course if human resources were unlimited and funds were unlimited, we would be able to provide indigent prisoners with all that they wanted in the way of transcripts in many other problem areas too.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: How often does the State Supreme Court have a master upon it or referee upon it, is that a matter of common practice or is it very rare?

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: I would say that it's a fairly common practice, one can pickup almost any volume of the California Supreme Court reports and it will have two or three such hearings reported in it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Do you know Mr. Weber the answer of the question or not, Mr. Justice Fortas just asked whether other states have the same procedure?

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: I made a very quick canvas of laws of the other states and there are a few, I think there's about five or so that still retain the common law procedure, many of the others have adopted by statute an appeal procedure, some others have converted writ review procedures into something that is virtually or equivalent to an appeal.

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: I think North Dakota has something that they call a Power of Superintending Control which is in effect a kind of appeal procedure.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Suppose his allegation is, I was tried and convicted and did not have the assistance of counsel and that's his petition for habeas corpus in the Superior Court, there is a hearing in the Superior Court or does it, at the conclusion of the hearing the trial judge concludes that the fact that is contrary he did have the assistance of counsel.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now he then goes in the Supreme Court with the identical petition, I didn't have the assistance of counsel at my trial and suggesting that in the face of a finding to the contrary that the Supreme Court would be interested with the transcript to go ahead and have it's own hearing in that petition.

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: Well, there if the allegation was sufficient they would call for a rule to show cause and the state well, I suppose it responds, he did have counsel and you would say I suppose you would say --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall you might have the transcript and you could say or without the transcript you could say it was found in the contrary in lower court.

context.speaker: Jack K. Weber
context.text: Well, you could just get the records from Superior Court filed from the original trial.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What if you did what if you did get the record and you attached a part of the transcript to your return, so he did have counsel and here is what was found by the Superior Court.

Glover v. St. Louis-San Francisco Railwa.speaker: Justice White
Glover v. St. Louis-San Francisco Railwa.case_name: Glover v. St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company
Glover v. St. Louis-San Francisco Railwa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 14, 1968

context.speaker: Donald W.Fisher
context.text: It should be presumed at least, perhaps I'm getting mixed in my syntax, I think the presumptions would certainly be that these members, the carrier members and the labor members, abide by the law do not countenance hostile or invidious racial discrimination and bring forth a correct construction and application of railroad collective bargaining agreements.

context.speaker: Donald W.Fisher
context.text: And, I think, as a matter of fact, it has been recognized by this Court that miscarriages of justice will probably result if judges who are not experts in railroad matters and are not familiar with the railroad parlance should attempt to interpret these agreements in the customs and practices that also are, at times, are embodied in the agreement.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, how do you get around Steel or worse?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It seems to me that it says, frankly, that this kind of a remedy before the Board, this isn't the kind of remedy that has to be exhausted because of the factors that Mr. Justice Harlan had mentioned and others.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Steel certainly just -- the defense was there.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They had exhausted the remedies and the Court has just -- just said that remedy isn't much of a remedy when this kind of a ch -- a great charge of racial discrimination is made.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: No, I'm asking about the interpretation of your statute.

context.speaker: Raymond F. Simon
context.text: In -- indeed Your Honor.

context.speaker: Raymond F. Simon
context.text: The legal answer is yes that they are as charged with subsequent judicial determinations as they are with knowledge of the law itself.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I -- I thought you said to Mr. Justice Stewart that there was no pre-warning that this would be the interpretation of the statute by the Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Raymond F. Simon
context.text: Oh, no.

context.speaker: Raymond F. Simon
context.text: No, I was answering Mr. Justice Stewart that no previous decisions --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You said that any test related to a jurors or juror was a dangerous test but and that you favors that formulation did not contribute to the verdict, well, what's the difference?

context.speaker: Roger S. Hanson
context.text: Well, perhaps there is no great difference.

context.speaker: Roger S. Hanson
context.text: I gathered Mr. Justice Harlan felt that might be some problem in attempting to for a court to say to a -- to put itself in the position of a jury and say, do we as the court think that this jury would've come up with difference.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, you call Mr. Justice Harlan dissented in Chapman.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I'm interested in your view.

context.speaker: Roger S. Hanson
context.text: Well, --

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: In other words, whether or not --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, the repealer of 137.

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But may I get back to Mr. Justice White asked you earlier?

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: Sure.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, how do you get under 137 the open housing ordinance to a vote?

context.speaker: Alvin C. Vinopal
context.text: I think with that I shall close.

context.speaker: Alvin C. Vinopal
context.text: Thank you gentlemen.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Carter, you have a few moments left.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Carter, how do you answer Justice White's question?

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: Well, Mr. Justice White's question about the repeal?

context.speaker: Robert L. Carter
context.text: I think that in terms of answering, it seems to me that Akron has done more than merely repealing the statute.

Immigration and Naturalization Service v.speaker: Justice Warren
Immigration and Naturalization Service v.case_name: Immigration and Naturalization Service v. Stanisic
Immigration and Naturalization Service v.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1969

context.speaker: Joseph J. Connolly
context.text: So, if the Government determines that he is not a refugee then by that factor -- by that fact the substantive provisions of the convention don't apply to him.

context.speaker: Joseph J. Connolly
context.text: If the Government determines that he is a refugee, then he is entitled to the discretionary relief and the Government will give him the discretionary relief under the statute.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I see.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Fedde, Mr. Justice Black would like to ask you a question --

context.speaker: G. Bernhard Fedde
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What I want to ask you about was this.

context.speaker: J. Minos Simon
context.text: It must make findings that directly affect the rights of individuals.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Naming persons.

context.speaker: J. Minos Simon
context.text: Naming persons.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now suppose I want to get back to Justice Harlan's question.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Suppose a legislative committee were set up and for this precise purpose that is to say to ascertain whether criminal laws have been violated and to name specific persons for that purpose.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Do you or do you not consider that that would be within the legislature's constitutional prerogative?

context.speaker: William A. Claerhout
context.text: Yes, there's no question about that.

context.speaker: William A. Claerhout
context.text: Now the -- in conclusion on that point, though we think that the petitioner received due process by protection of the jury and we think that this would be the same in 1968, as it was in 1934.

context.speaker: William A. Claerhout
context.text: Finally, the alibi instruction --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, before you get to that, on just what as Justice Marshall has presented to you, this is an almost a clear concession that they were not, these notes were not the documents signed or written by the petitioner, isn't it?

context.speaker: William A. Claerhout
context.text: I think Mr. Chief Justice based on expert opinion, this is all we have to go on, yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: It says the examination has been made of the above described material as requested.

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: In fact, in a number of those cases, the court seems to have commented or to have assumed that the assignment was good under state law.

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: Finally, there is a lengthy suggestion in the brief that somehow even though this might not be good in the case of an assignment where the real parties and interest are citizens of the same state, that the court should be more lenient or more tolerant with respect to this matter where the real party and interests are two aliens.

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: I must confess I'm somewhat unable to follow this --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Mr. Lyons, may I just get back a moment to your colloquy with Justice White.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Did I understand you correctly to say that, the test here of collusion should be their attention of an economic interest in this instance is 95% of the 66 and two-thirds but the assignor?

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: That's certainly one of the tests, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Mr. Lyons, may I just get back a moment to your colloquy with Justice White.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Did I understand you correctly to say that, the test here of collusion should be their attention of an economic interest in this instance is 95% of the 66 and two-thirds but the assignor?

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: That's certainly one of the tests, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Well, it's s not -- I thought you also suggested to Justice White that if he lost when he had nothing to return --

context.speaker: Dennis G.Lyons
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Then what?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It does -- got all the terminology of a patent agreement with respect to the exhibit C rights it's –- purports to give the other party and exclusive right to the use of it, it smells like a patent agreement.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And as I understand it what you say here is that even if the patent aspects unlawful as a matter of federal law, you can resort to state contract law and still collect the same amounts of money and certain practically the same rights.

context.speaker: Peter R. Cohen
context.text: I don't believe --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Maybe I misunderstand you but that's what I've been trying to get at in my questions here to see whether that is in fact that they are in now based on your colloquy with Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It seems to me that indeed that is your theory.

context.speaker: Peter R. Cohen
context.text: No, I don't think that's my theory perhaps I'm not stating as I should be stating but what I'm trying to get across is that the basis of the bargain between Adkins and the Lear was not the grant by Adkins to Lear of a federal patent right.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Let's see if I get this correct.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: First, is this Chinese puzzle of that -- of extrapolating the six months sentence for lascivious carriage in to a three months commitment to the State Farm for women, if its three months and we regard that as a sentence and you get an exact identity with the length of the sentence under the danger resulting from being a female statute.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And if that is so, then we have the problem of concurrent sentences because of lascivious carriage conviction is not before us.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Then, if we can consider the raise up solacritor criminal statute, the danger of being a woman in Newhaven of Connecticut, then I suppose that -- then we get into the questions that Mr. Justice Black was raising.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Is that a correct analysis of it?

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: That is correct analysis but I don't think that the sentencing provisions are really not much of the Chinese puzzle.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Carroll --

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: I didn't realize that, may I -- excuse me Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Carroll, -- oh, excuse Chief.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: He's going to answer Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: I'm still trying to come up with something to answer that.

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: Well, Your Honor, it could come to that.

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: But I think because this conviction stands on independent state grounds and because you don't have the --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, what independent state then?

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: The conviction under the other statute.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, do you mean there's another -- that's the one you were talking to Justice Fortas?

context.speaker: George F. Carroll, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That's pretty long way in this.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: The idea was to see that the court before sentencing a man was satisfied that he wasn't pleading guilty because of desperation or whatever it may be, wanting to put an end on uncertain situation or whatever, or pressure or whatnot that the judge has to be satisfied that there's a factual basis for the plea.

context.speaker: Maurice J. McCarthy
context.text: This is a second part of our argument Your Honor that there is an abuse of discretion in this case.

context.speaker: Maurice J. McCarthy
context.text: I don't think that --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I understand that your brief on pages from 24 to pages 29 some 5 or 6 with bold printed pages, the thrust of your argument is almost precisely what Mr. Justice Fortas' questions have suggested, i.e. that there was not compliance in this case with the final sentence in newly amended Rule 11.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: Maurice J. McCarthy
context.text: Exactly, Your Honor but I frame it in terms of an abuse of discretion in the part of the District Court because I don't find that language to be sufficiently specific.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But this language is left identical.

context.speaker: Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
context.text: Yes, Your Honor and the -- as a matter of fact the Congress ratified this Court's construction of that language in the Falbo and Estep cases by providing that no basis in fact standard should be the one that's applied in judicial review here.

context.speaker: Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
context.text: That of course is the provision that the language that Estep adopted in delineating the stand --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: What would you say if that suggest that the exhaustion doctrine that Falbo and Estep was simply an interpretation the affection that Justice White referred to, why is that to be end of this case?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Ordinarily we don't overrule cases that turn on statutory and our interpretation statutes that Congress can change over night.

context.speaker: Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
context.text: Well I would like to think that that's the end of the case and it seem --

National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel.speaker: Justice Warren
National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel Packing Company, Inc.
National Labor Relations Board v. Gissel.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 26, 1969

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: And that after he asked for it, you have an election in which you have the same rights and free speech as both sides as though the Union had asked for an election.

context.speaker: Albert Gore
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Albert Gore
context.text: Now, I should add that this is been the view of the Fourth Circuit before Logan Packing and it was expressed in the Florence Printing Company case an overnight express.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, how may I -- may I ask about what the very difference there is between you and Mr. Manoli about who must initiate this election in the circumstances of Mr. Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: As I understood you, you said that it was then the duty of the employer to request election --

context.speaker: Albert Gore
context.text: Correct.

National Labor Relations Board v. Strong.speaker: Justice Fortas
National Labor Relations Board v. Strong.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Strong
National Labor Relations Board v. Strong.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1968

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I know you say that and then the arbitrator may or may not allow it and if he does agree with you, the Court may or may not overrule.

context.speaker: Charles G. Bakaly, Jr.
context.text: It would be very surprised, Mr. Justice Fortas, that the Court will overrule an arbitrator.

context.speaker: Charles G. Bakaly, Jr.
context.text: If he rules on our favor, we would have to take what is the decision.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That's because of what Justice Douglas wrote in the trilogy.

context.speaker: Charles G. Bakaly, Jr.
context.text: Of what this Court said.

context.speaker: Charles G. Bakaly, Jr.
context.text: There's some other provisions but from Labor Board he's going to in this case after interpreting this Collective Bargaining Agreement.

National Labor Relations Board v. Wyman-.speaker: Justice Stewart
National Labor Relations Board v. Wyman-.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Wyman-Gordon Company
National Labor Relations Board v. Wyman-.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 03, 1969

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: Certainly, there has been no such case in the Courts of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: As I understand, it's not -- is it your submission that the failure would be an unfair labor practice?

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice, I think it would, but the unfair labor practice proceeding is somewhat complicated and prolonged and makes it very difficult to carry out elections promptly, which is the Board's duty under Section 9 of the Act.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The case is so far, as I understood your answer to Mr. Justice Fortas, have all arise as this one did, that is, by -- and in all the other cases, the District Courts enforced the Board's efforts to require the employer to furnish the list.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: I think there's one District Court decision in New Jersey which refused to enforce it, all of those which have gone to Courts of Appeals, the Board's effort to enforce has been sustained except for this case.

context.speaker: Larry B. Sitton
context.text: And I don't think the rule would go that far.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, suppose he's not out on bail, he is in jail, he waits two years to be tried, does the Constitution require to get a fair trial?

context.speaker: Larry B. Sitton
context.text: I think by natural extension, it could, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In answer to Justice Black, you said this was a one of the requirements of a fair trial.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: I thought this was a double jeopardy case, isn't it?

context.speaker: Larry B. Sitton
context.text: We do raise that issue too, Your Honor, that it violates double jeopardy because it is in effect a multiple punishment.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now, what is your reply to that?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: That first the sentence has -- the reply is twofold.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: First, that any justice of this Court just as the entire Court has the right to interrupt the sentence for the purpose of preventing the cause from becoming moot and I believe the Government concede to that power --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And you say that just as Mr. Justice Douglas' order did that?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: How?

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: How?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: By ordering that the petitioner be released from confinement.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: But under the rule, criminal justice I understand it that the computation of the amount of time that the man has served does not depend on whether he is or he's not in confinement.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: That's the rule that Justice Stewart is talking about.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Unless there is some foremost suspension of sentence?

context.speaker: James Van R. Springer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: James Van R. Springer
context.text: I might suggest which is that he has of course been under some restraints.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I know but Mr. Justice Marshall asked you what is the reason for the provision that saying that sentence runs whether you're confined or not.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, let's assume the case where he is not confined at all on appeal the sentence still runs, why?

context.speaker: James Van R. Springer
context.text: There are number of reasons perhaps there are peculiar rules about the computation of sentences within the service, pretend there are no concurrence sentences.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Never properly raise and therefore we will not consider it and that might have been a perfectly good ground.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But in fact, they did consider Miranda and Escobedo and everything else.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: They did consider the federal question and pass on it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: So, doesn't that as Justice Harlan says (Voice Overlap)?

context.speaker: Lonny F. Zwiener
context.text: Well, I would not concede that it would.

context.speaker: Lonny F. Zwiener
context.text: I think that if I have been right the opinion, I would have written on a different basis, I will distinguish Miranda differently.

context.speaker: Howard Mendelow
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, you asked me the question a little while ago and I'm afraid that I didn't have the answer to Mr. Justice Fortas, I can only assume from the record that he was booked for the crime for which he was ultimately tried.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: You don't know whether that's so or not?

context.speaker: Howard Mendelow
context.text: Well, the only way I can bring this clear to the Court, I do not know but the only way I can infer from the record is that 25 hours after his arrest, he was placed in a lineup and the victim of this particular robbery that he was arrested for was called down to identify someone --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Is there any -- and you also said in response to Justice Marshall's question as I understand it that, there are no cases under this Florida Statute?

context.speaker: Howard Mendelow
context.text: Yes, there are.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Well, what's the maximum period of detention? How long can a person be held without being charged or taken before a magistrate?

context.speaker: Edsel W. Haws
context.text: The objection was made not that you're requiring him to incriminate himself on a matter not charged but you're going into matters --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Beyond the direct testimony?

context.speaker: Edsel W. Haws
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But unless you utilize the concurring sentence rule Mr. Justice Brennan was asking you about it.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It seems to me that Raley against Ohio and Murphy against Waterfront and cases like that really are very relevant.

context.speaker: Edsel W. Haws
context.text: Well, --

Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.speaker: Justice Fortas
Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.case_name: Perkins v. Standard Oil of California
Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 23, 1969

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: You would agree wouldn't you that the fact that Regal sold at a lower price than Perkins does not establish a violation of law standing alone?

context.speaker: Earl W. Kintner
context.text: Not standing alone sir.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: I know.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: As I understood Mr. Justice White's question and the same question I have in my mind, could you state as succinctly just what the theory was on which you tried this case.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: It wouldn't just let Regal sold for a lower price than Perkins.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: What is the theory on which this case was tried?

Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.speaker: Justice Douglas
Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.case_name: Perkins v. Standard Oil of California
Perkins v. Standard Oil of California.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 22, 1969

context.speaker: Richard J. Maclaury
context.text: They were given in the alternative, the jury was told that it must found -- find and I'm reading at second line, to that the reasonable probable effect of the discrimination may have been to substantially lessen competition and then in the disjunctive or tend to create a monopoly in the line of commerce or --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Richard J. Maclaury
context.text: -- then Robinson-Patman and to destroy or prevent competition with Perkins of Oregon, etcetera, etcetera.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: You told Justice White as I recall it, there's no evidence in Signal control Regal?

context.speaker: Richard J. Maclaury
context.text: There was no evidence that Signal controlled Regal.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: How naïve do you want us to be?

context.speaker: Bruce Bromley
context.text: The House draws that line sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Oh, then the Court has not jurisdiction to draw lines.

context.speaker: Bruce Bromley
context.text: Except in cases of under perversions, sir.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And in response to Justice Black I take it an exclusion solely on the grounds of rights would not be within -- would not be within the category of other perversions as you see it.

context.speaker: Bruce Bromley
context.text: In my opinion it would not sir, although, clearly unconstitutional, clearly improper.

context.speaker: Bruce Bromley
context.text: Now, very little has been --

Presbyterian Church in United States v..speaker: Justice Stewart
Presbyterian Church in United States v..case_name: Presbyterian Church in United States v. Mary Elizabeth Blue Hull Memorial Presbyterian Church
Presbyterian Church in United States v..title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 09, 1968

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You’re answer to me now is, “We are not”.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In the determination here whether or not this is a matter of church law, we witness to this property any authority of the state by whatever property concept.

context.speaker: Charles L. Gowen
context.text: I don’t think the State Courts have a right to determine the -- where the property goes but that’s a matter for determination by the ecclesiastical courts.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: (Voice overlap) to what Justice White asked you earlier.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It was true, wasn’t it that we were able to find in Kedroff that there was a provision of Canon Law that dealt with this problem?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And if you are going to suggest that there is one in -- we have your Book of Church Order here but can you suggest what the provision was now that you referred us to earlier?

Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.speaker: Justice Brennan
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.case_name: Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Company
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1969

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They may borrow some state law, but it's still federal law.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: I see what you mean.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And, it seems to me, you're going -- if I understand the opinion of the Court of Appeals on the analysis that Mr. Justice White has just suggested, the Court of Appeals held that, to answer Justice Black's question, the only remedy is the federal remedy under the Death on the High Seas Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: There is no state remedy under Section 7 or otherwise of the High Seas Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The only remedy is the federal remedy.

Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.speaker: Justice Brennan
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.case_name: Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Company
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1969

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They may borrow some state law, but it's still federal law.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: I see what you mean.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And, it seems to me, you're going -- if I understand the opinion of the Court of Appeals on the analysis that Mr. Justice White has just suggested, the Court of Appeals held that, to answer Justice Black's question, the only remedy is the federal remedy under the Death on the High Seas Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: There is no state remedy under Section 7 or otherwise of the High Seas Act.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The only remedy is the federal remedy.

Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.speaker: Justice Brennan
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.case_name: Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Company
Rodrigue v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Comp.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1969

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I'm surprised to hear you suggest that, nevertheless, there may be a state remedy if the proceeding is brought in a State Court.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor, I didn't mean --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, I thought that's what you answered to Mr. Justice Black.

context.speaker: James E. Diaz
context.text: He -- I had understood his question as to the interpretation of Section 7 of the Death on the High Seas Act outside of the contents of the Outer Continental Shelf.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well --

Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.speaker: Justice Stewart
Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.case_name: Scofield v. National Labor Relations Board
Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 14, 1969

context.speaker: James Urdan
context.text: They were not agreed upon in the sense that they were a limit on the employee.

context.speaker: James Urdan
context.text: The employee was free to work, free to make more than the ceiling permitted and the employer had to pay him under the collective agreement.

context.speaker: James Urdan
context.text: There was collective bargaining over the ceilings as to the general level of the ceilings, but never were the ceilings accepted in bargaining as a limit on the individual and as the individual who is complaining here.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan's question exposes what for me has been a difficulty in reading the briefs and to answer this argument and that is the apparent disagreement among the parties as to what the facts are.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You state as number one on the questions presented, referring to the ceilings, you talk about production quotas established and enforced by the union and the government trying to persuade us that really these things, while not explicitly written out of the collective bargaining agreement, are nonetheless where by custom, practice and basic recognition were part and parcel of the agreement between the union and the employer and that makes for two quite different cases.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I'm interested in knowing which case do we have before us?

Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.speaker: Justice Stewart
Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.case_name: Scofield v. National Labor Relations Board
Scofield v. National Labor Relations Boa.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 14, 1969

context.speaker: James Urdan
context.text: In fact, the union concedes this very point in its brief.

context.speaker: James Urdan
context.text: We have here --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: If the employer you said tried to discipline the employee for this type of restriction, the employer could and you said your opponent concedes that, I don't understand the statement.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You mean, the -- I suppose you are now answering Justice White's question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You are saying that the employer could fire the employee for not trying to make over time, is that it?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: What are you --

context.speaker: Joe S. Moss
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, what are the facts that we should be develop?

context.speaker: Joe S. Moss
context.text: Facts developed was whether or not he has been deprived of these asserted constitutional rights --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I mean, if we're going to bring him in for that kind of hearing and as Mr. Justice White pointed out his petition was either for a trial or for dismissal of the indictment, why not send them back to you and let it be brought there for the trial on the new merits?

context.speaker: Joe S. Moss
context.text: Oh, I'm sure it be done if Your Honor so ordered, but you bear in mind, we don't have the United States Government of the party to this suit.

context.speaker: Joe S. Moss
context.text: He's filed the lawsuit against the district judge is going to preside over his trial if we haven't get him, and there's nobody else.

Sniadach v. Family Finance Corp. of Bay.speaker: Justice Fortas
Sniadach v. Family Finance Corp. of Bay.case_name: Sniadach v. Family Finance Corp. of Bay View
Sniadach v. Family Finance Corp. of Bay.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 21, 1969

context.speaker: Sheldon D. Frank
context.text: No, I don't believe it is, Mr. Justice Fortas.

context.speaker: Sheldon D. Frank
context.text: I believe that a garnishment is a remedy which is afforded to the creditor, strictly a feature of the legislature, no question of it.

context.speaker: Sheldon D. Frank
context.text: But it was given to the creditor because he had no other remedy, and I think it is more important today than it was 15 years ago or 20 years ago.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Well, the return to Mr. Justice Stewart's question, I'm not clear about it.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Let's suppose you got a judgment.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Can't you levy execution -- You have a procedure by which you levy execution there, don't you?

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: That is the nub of the problem isn't it, because that is exactly what we are saying.

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: We are saying also that even under the circumstances, these circumstances Mr. Justice Fortas pointed out, that the act could then be coupled with other acts that in and up itself now brings it out of the simple due process problems of a criminal statute and close it with First Amendment problems.

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: And I might point out --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Don't you think there'd be any First Amendment problem and the case put to you by Mr. Justice Fortas?

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: Not necessarily.

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: Not necessarily because on its face, there's no restriction of speech, but there may be as for example as apply, the person may be doing the burning and shouting that United States is not belong in that--

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: The vagueness question though dispose of in a footnote was still considered.

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: We have pointed out that the statute was vague because he never said what flag they were talking about.

context.speaker: David T. Goldstick
context.text: That was disposed of in a footnote and that was the total consideration given to the vagueness argument by Judge Fuld.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, except there's something else that the fact is bothered me Mr. Goldstick and that reason I ask you about your answer to Justice Fortas question.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Judge Fuld in Footnote 1, appearing on 4a of the appendix of this case, it seems to say before the highest Court in New York that this statute simply prohibits public mutilation of the flag and that's why the way he construes the statute.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And of course, we have to take that construction as though the statute were written that way under we've excepted conventional doctrines in this Court.

context.speaker: David L. Uelmen
context.text: And that issue, of course, the issue of money damages, still makes this a live issue or a case of controversy for this Court because even if this Court does, pursuant to a mootness point, reverse and remand it and vacate the judgment, then these individual plaintiffs and the class that they represent will not be restored to the dues that they paid and would still have the claim for that money.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But, Mr. Uelmen.

context.speaker: David L. Uelmen
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I expect, as Justice Fortas suggested, this ins -- this case may not be moot.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But, if you're familiar with Monrosa and cases of that kind where there have been events, occurrences since the grant of certiorari which make it, in our judgment, a case not to be decided, we dismiss it as improperly granted.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And, I expect that's the choice here, isn't it?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Very well.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Matter submitted.

context.speaker: Lee Leibik
context.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Leibik, Justice Harlan would like to ask you --

context.speaker: Lee Leibik
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: A question.

context.speaker: Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
context.text: Well I think that's an important distinction that we have habeas preserved where the –-

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, how do you preserve only where he is sent to prison?

context.speaker: Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
context.text: Yeah but it's really --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Otherwise as I understand your answers to Mr. Justice Fortas no matter how defective the Court Martial proceeding, if the Court of Military Appeals doesn't review it, you can't ever get any judicial review.

context.speaker: Edwin L. Weisl, Jr.
context.text: One, being deprived of one's liberty or one's life to which habeas also attaches, is a far more injurious and then –-

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You don't think dismal from the service.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But if the court, if a judge or jury found the accumulation of the unreasonable by whatever applicable standards there were you're suggestion is that nevertheless a taxpayer should be allowed not to be taxed on the unreasonable accumulation because he had a good faith view that this was -- that his business needed these accumulation?

context.speaker: Richard L. Braunstein
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Richard L. Braunstein
context.text: I think what we're saying that whatever his motivation is he's not looking to avoid tax but he honestly believes that --

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Mr. Braunstein, consideration that bothers me in this case following the quote by Mr. Justice White, is it's arguable that the standard adopted by the Court of Appeals in what you're contending here is contrary really to what the Congress expressly provided and that in a way it undermines the specific language of Section 533 (a).

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: And 533 (a) really makes the test of that intent to avoid stockholder tax a very minor consequence as I read it, it says that once you find that the earnings of the corporation are permitted or accumulate beyond the reasonable needs of the business that that “shall be determinative of the purpose to avoid the income tax with respect to shareholders unless the corporation by the preponderance of the evidence shall prove to the contrary.”

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Now, those are very rugged standards but they're Congress' standards whether one makes a good, bad, or indifferent they are in the law.

United States v. Montgomery County Board.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. Montgomery County Board.case_name: United States v. Montgomery County Board of Education
United States v. Montgomery County Board.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1969

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I can see that if all -- if it just so happened that all the teachers in high schools and all the high schools were white and all the teachers of all the grade schools were Negro, then a requirement is really two in each school would obviously require some shifting between high school and grade school.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But I'm not -- I don't -- I just like to know if there's anything really helpful in the record.

context.speaker: Joseph D. Phelps
context.text: Not Mr. Justice White --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I think your appendix Mr. Phelps on page 36 of your brief, I think that would furnish the ingredients of the information in which Mr. Justice Fortas have manifested in interest if we knew which of those schools were high schools and which are elementary schools.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Some are identified, others are not.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For example, there in (Inaudible) and so on are simply --

United States v. Skelly Oil Company.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. Skelly Oil Company.case_name: United States v. Skelly Oil Company
United States v. Skelly Oil Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 15, 1969

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: And that is the item but our position is that Congress says, deliberately used different words and that “deduction” is a different word than “item” and that we still have left to determine what is the appropriate amount of the deduction and on that I suggest that the Ludey, Ilfeld, and Arrowsmith cases appoint the way.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I think your point is, Mr. Solicitor General, that subsection 2 here is not a definition of the amount of the deduction.

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: Exactly, Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That's where you and Justice Fortas find yourself --

context.speaker: Erwin N. Griswold
context.text: That's exactly the point that I'm concerned, that I have not able to make my position thoroughly.

context.speaker: Abe Fortas
context.text: Well, what is its function though?

United States v. Skelly Oil Company.speaker: Justice White
United States v. Skelly Oil Company.case_name: United States v. Skelly Oil Company
United States v. Skelly Oil Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 15, 1969

context.speaker: Robert J. Casey
context.text: I am saying that this taxpayer incurred a business expense in the years 1952 through 1957, that is the reduction of his mineral property by reason of the severance and sale of the mineral.

context.speaker: Robert J. Casey
context.text: That that deduction in those years was computed not on a basis of the taxpayer's cost, not on the basis of a discovery value, but on ad hoc formula basis which the Congress has proposed and the Congress has said that you take 27.5% of your gross income from the property limited by 50% of your taxable income from the property.

context.speaker: Robert J. Casey
context.text: That is a separate and completely different business expense from the settlement of the litigation which occurred in the year before this Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But again, Mr. Justice Fortas suggested that this settlement been paid at the year your income defining what it had produced?

context.speaker: Robert J. Casey
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And your depletion?

Universal Interpretive Shuttle Corporati.speaker: Justice White
Universal Interpretive Shuttle Corporati.case_name: Universal Interpretive Shuttle Corporation v. Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Commission
Universal Interpretive Shuttle Corporati.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 21, 1968

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It is about the port to run these vessels unconstitutional after?

context.speaker: Russell W. Cunningham
context.text: It is my understanding that it is running on Constitution Avenue and it will run.

context.speaker: Russell W. Cunningham
context.text: How else can it run, it has to turn around down at the capital and run back up Mr. Justice White and they're also talking about running --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Do you think the issue that Mr. Justice Fortas raised with the counsel a while ago is really here, whether or not -- whether or not the Secretary has the authority without consulting the Commission to operate the service over -- over District of Columbia streets?

context.speaker: Russell W. Cunningham
context.text: Yes sir, very much sir.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I didn't understand that.

context.speaker: Giles K. Ratcliffe
context.text: The appeal from there was to the common plea court where it was trial de novo.

context.speaker: Giles K. Ratcliffe
context.text: Then of course an appeal from that to the Court of Criminal Appeals would be treated as a county matter.

context.speaker: Giles K. Ratcliffe
context.text: Transcripts would have been furnished under the state law and say this problem didn't arise until just a couple of years.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But in answer to Justice Black's question now, not the last couple of years, where is the appeal, where is the --?

context.speaker: Giles K. Ratcliffe
context.text: It is directed to the Court of Criminal Appeals just as it was before from the Court of Common Plea.

context.speaker: Giles K. Ratcliffe
context.text: In other words, this is --

context.speaker: David J. Young
context.text: So, true, the lawsuit is late but is it late solely that 400,000 voters in Ohio's right to suffer should be denied.

context.speaker: David J. Young
context.text: I agreed that the lawsuit is late but I don't think it's too late to -- I don't think relief should be denied just because these people didn't file earlier.

context.speaker: David J. Young
context.text: I don't think the Doctrine of Laches would be applicable when we're talking about the voting rights of an excessive 400,000 citizens in Ohio.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, these in light of the fact mean that under Justice Stewart's order there is in fact an existence the ballots which contain the designation.

context.speaker: David J. Young
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Unless for other reasons that designation should be deleted.

context.speaker: Charles S. Lopeman
context.text: The conflict of possible conflict between the rights, duties and authorities of electors under the federal constitution and the rights of -- and the requirements of law binding them.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, that was decided in Ray against Blair, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That question if I understand the question you're raising.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That was the case and which Alabama did require by state law that the electors vote for the national candidates of their party and this Court in Ray against Blair and opinion by Mr. Justice Reed and all of that did not violate either Article II, Section 1 or (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Charles S. Lopeman
context.text: Yes, that's correct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But is there a provision of Ohio law which purports to require electors pledge to a certain presidential candidate to vote for him?

context.speaker: Jerry Gordon
context.text: We said subject to -- if a state can prove a compelling justification to --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: You can't take the one of those, can you?

context.speaker: Jerry Gordon
context.text: It's hard for me to, Your Honor, because we've examined the reasons that have historically been offered and we (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So you really are as Mr. Justice Black suggests the claim very -- come very close to claim in absolute right to be on the ballot?

context.speaker: Jerry Gordon
context.text: The party is on -- the small political party --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Right, yes.

Zenith Radio Corporation v. Hazeltine Re.speaker: Justice Stewart
Zenith Radio Corporation v. Hazeltine Re.case_name: Zenith Radio Corporation v. Hazeltine Research, Inc.
Zenith Radio Corporation v. Hazeltine Re.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 22, 1969

context.speaker: Thomas C. Mcconnell
context.text: You could take judicial notice, but you might also, with all due deference, take judicial notice of a statement in those reports that they have been -- Zenith has been restricted in these markets by restrictions of these pools and that they are trying their best to fight out from under them but, so far, they haven't been able to do it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You would agree that we can take judicial notice of those annual reports?

context.speaker: Thomas C. Mcconnell
context.text: Well, I don't think that --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: By a parity of reasoning that a support to your answer to Justice Fortas just now.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Mcconnell
context.text: The reason that I have to take the position that I took with Justice Fortas is this record is closed.

context.speaker: Thomas C. Mcconnell
context.text: There's no other way to show what happens there, no other way.
